COSC461.Greed

Class GreedGame

  • java.lang.Object
    • COSC461.Greed.GreedGame

  • public class GreedGame
extends java.lang.Object
    Greed Game core implementation. Note: While reasonably decoupled from any particular interface, this mostly assumes a simple text console is being used for play. A nicer (but more complex) implementation might involve using: GridWord instead of ASCII output.

    Author:
    Adam J. Conover, D.Sc. <aconover@towson.edu>

      • canMove

        public static boolean canMove(int[][] board,
                              Location loc,
                              Direction dir)
        Determine if a makeMove in a given direction is valid.
        Parameters:
        board - Board to test
        loc - Location within board
        dir - Direction to makeMove
        Returns:
        true if movement in a direction is possible, false otherwise.

      • testMove

        public static StateNode testMove(int[][] board,
                                 int score,
                                 Location loc,
                                 Direction dir)
        TEST MOVE without altering the internal state of the game. This is designed to allow for easier "backtracking" in any AI code. In most "Functional Languages", immutable structures exist which make this far easier.

        IMPLEMENTATION NOTE: I use the a "$" prefix for local "Scratch" vars in this method that are purely local copies and need to be explicitly copied to modify the objects state. (You really should NEVER use "$" in any Java class or method name though).

        Parameters:
        board - The Board to test
        score - The Current/Reference Score
        loc - The Current Location
        dir - The Direction to makeMove
        Returns:
        A StateNode Object which contains the result of the makeMove.

      • testMove

        public static StateNode testMove(StateNode parent,
                                 Direction dir)
        Test a move using an existing node as the reference point. Testing a node for a given direction can be considered "adding a child" to the current node in the virtual tree.
        Parameters:
        parent - The node to test
        dir - The Direction to test for the given node.
        Returns:
        A new StateNode that is the result of testing the parent node against a given move direction.

      • testMove

        public static StateNode testMove(GreedGame parent,
                                 Direction dir)
        This is just a convenience method which accepts and entire Game Object. Test a move using an existing game as the reference point. Testing a node for a given direction can be considered "adding a child" to the current node in the virtual tree.
        Parameters:
        parent - The node to test
        dir - The Direction to test for the given node.
        Returns:
        A new StateNode that is the result of testing the parent node against a given move direction.

      • getBoard

        public int[][] getBoard()
        Return a COPY of the board so it can't be modified outside this class. Note: Google's Guava library does have Immutable collections, but this just avoids the need for a third part lib (or a lot more code) and is not THAT inefficient for our purposes. (https://github.com/google/guava/wiki/PrimitivesExplained)
        Returns:
        COPY of the board

      • getLocation

        public Location getLocation()
        Return a COPY of the location so it can't be modified outside this class.
        Returns:
        COPY of the current location.

      • getScore

        public int getScore()
        Return "Copy" (value) of the current score.
        Returns:
        Value of Current Score

      • getAvailableDirections

        public static java.util.Set<Direction> getAvailableDirections(int[][] board,
                                                              Location loc)
        Get a set of all movement directions that are legal from a given position.
        Parameters:
        board - the board to test.
        loc - current Location
        Returns:
        Set of all valid directions from a given location.

      • getAvailableDirections

        public static java.util.Set<Direction> getAvailableDirections(StateNode node)
        Get a set of all movement directions that are legal from a given position.
        Parameters:
        node - the current state to test.
        Returns:
        Set of all valid directions from a given location.

      • getAvailableDirections

        public java.util.Set<Direction> getAvailableDirections()
        Get a set of all movement directions that are legal from the current position.
        Returns:
        Set of all valid directions

      • makeMove

        public StateNode makeMove(Direction dir)
        Perform actual makeMove in game, no take-backs. Does not return a full StateNode object since the current object state information can be obtained via other methods of this class.
        Parameters:
        dir - Direction to makeMove
        Returns:
        the score of the individual makeMove itself.
        See Also:
        getBoard(), getLocation(), getScore()

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Obligatory toString().
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        Human Readable (and playable) board representation.

      • asNode

        public StateNode asNode()
        Returns the current board state as a StateNode. Use this to get a copy of the current board that can be freely manipulated without altering the actual game state.
        Returns:
        The StateNode representing the current state of the actual game.

      • state

        public StateNode state()
        Just an alias for asNode
        Returns:
        the state node of the current game.

      • hasPlayableMoves

        public boolean hasPlayableMoves()
        Returns:
        true iff has playable moves.
